description.narrative: Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

description.narrative: Improve policies, laws, regulations, and administrative practices affecting the private sector. Includes reducing barriers to competition and unwarranted distortions to market prices; reducing policy and regulatory barriers to establishing, operating, and closing businesses; strengthening the legal framework surrounding property rights that is fair to both men and women, contract enforcement, and dispute resolution, along with the administration of those laws; reducing incentives for corruption and promoting transparent business practices; strengthening the legal framework surrounding intellectual property rights; and improving laws and regulations affecting the creation, dissemination, and use of technology. It also includes improving policies and regulations affecting technology choices and production behaviors with environmental impacts; and improving policies, laws, and regulations affecting hiring and firing of workers, wages, working conditions, and collective bargaining. Includes support for specific improvements as well as efforts to strengthen the institutions that contribute to designing and implementing further improvements.

The policies, laws, regulations, and administrative practices affecting international trade and investment and the public and private sector institutions that support sustained, locally driven improvements in the trade environment that benefit both men and women.

Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

The purpose of the activity is to conserve illegally traded wildlife from the wider-Caribbean region. The activity will achieve this purpose by reducing the illegal collection and poaching of wildlife for international trade related to demand for pets or collections, food, medicines, jewelry and crafts.

Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

The purpose of the USAID Caribbean Sustainable Ecosystems Activity is to reduce threats to coastal and marine biodiversity in priority areas in the caribbean. This is consistent with the USAID Biodiversity Policy and the USAID Climate Strategy. The activity will enhance climate resilience and human well-being of local communities, women, youth, and other marginalized groups. Specific biodiversity focal interests include key ecosystems such as mangroves, seagrass beds, and coral reefs, as well as communities of invertebrates, sharks, rays, reef fish, marine turtles, and marine mammals, with special emphasis on manatees.

title.narrative: Regional Trade Facilitation and Border Management

description.narrative: (USAID Central America Regional): The Activity will contribute to broad-based economic growth in Central America by enhancing regional integration and improving trade facilitation. .Funded activities include: support the regional Customs Union process; increase transparency and efficiency of trade procedures by improving border management coordination; implement multilateral commitments of the WTO's Trade Facilitation Agreement; and improve product registration. This will be achieved through training for trade related government agencies and private sector stakeholders and enhancing IT connectivity of border control agencies. RFID technology will be used to promote electronic transmission of documents to reduce times to cross borders..The Activity supports the CEN's Prosperity pillar and the priorities established in the 2017 NT Miami Conference. It will also contribute to the GFSS' IR2: Strengthen and Expand Access to Markets and Trade.

(USAID Central America Regional): This activity supports biodiversity conservation in several significantly biodiverse regions in Central America. The activity supports the Mission's Regional Development Objective 3: "Improved Management of Transboundary Environmental and Health Threats" by seeking to improve the livelihoods of coastal communities by promoting sustainable use of natural resources. USAID will strengthen coastal landscape management practices and governance in highly sensitive coastal ecosystems on which many people's livelihoods depend. USAID will address critical threats to the region's coastal biodiversity, natural resources, and incentivize sustainable use and conservation practices to preserve the region's biodiversity. Programming will strengthen biocommerce opportunities in selected areas by training small and medium enterprises on how to add value to their products and reach new markets. Further, USAID will integrate biodiversity conservation principles in the small and medium sized commercial activities such as sustainable fishing, nature-based tourism, and mangrove honey production. It will continue to strengthen the governance of conservation and the sustainable use of biodiversity in the region. The activity will design and support implementation of landscape management plans and provide technical assistance to establish an evidence-based monitoring mechanism for improved biological and livelihood indicators. The activity will partner with local organizations focusing on providing economic opportunities for those whose livelihoods rely on and impact natural resources, are most vulnerable to the depletion of those resources, and are likely migrants. This work includes a social inclusion strategy that seeks to identify and reduce gender gaps and increase development opportunities for women and youth. USAID will strengthen rootedness and reduce irregular migration by improving the livelihoods through sustainable use of local natural resource

description.narrative: The project seeks to support national and transboundary institutions to effectively manage their water resources and address water security risks while conserving the environment to enable the Northern Central American Region to prosper in the face of increasing climate variability and change. The Activity will address the following three strategic objectives to accomplish its goal and meet its target: Objective 1: Improved collaboration and capacity of transboundary, cross-sectoral, and national institutions for evidence-based, climate-smart water resources management. Objective 2: Improved management of water security risks and violence prevention by users in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. Objective 3: Mechanisms for financing resilient water resources management assessed and utilized

Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

The initiative will strengthen objective investigative reporting skills of independent media in Central America to inform the public on corruption, while promoting government transparency, accountability, and respect for human rights. It will also support greater collaboration among independent media outlets and journalists from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua in their investigative work and expand access to services for journalists to manage their physical, digital, and psychosocial safety while working in high-risk environments.

description.narrative: The Regional Trade and Investment Activity is aimed at increasing regional integration and trade investment primarily in El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras, with a focus on clean energy investments.

Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Through this Regional GDA, USAID, in partnership with the private sector, will continue creating safe spaces for youth learning and recreation to foster youth leadership, self-esteem, and solidarity in the selected communities in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. Activities will further engage the private sector, local government, and individual volunteers in social action. USAID fosters civic participation, as well as youth leadership and advocacy, to expand a regional youth movement against violence to improve citizen security within the region.

(USAID Central America Regional): .The activity will reduce greenhouse gas emissions by establishing and applying incentives to reduce deforestation and degradation of forests and other land uses (REDD +); and reduce the vulnerability of human populations to climate change in Central America and the Dominican Republic by integrating geospatial technologies and Earth monitoring observations into development decisions. ..Funding will support Centro Clima, a digital information platform center, to provide demand-driven climate change adaptation information to farmers throughout Central America so they have the tools to mitigate risk and distribute technologies for better decision-making to increase resilience to climate change. Through partnerships with regional organizations, climate change information will be delivered to a variety of end users in thematic information networks, including coffee and agriculture, water, energy, marine coastal biodiversity, and disaster risk reduction....

title.narrative: CARSI ESF-Regional E-CAM-Regional Academy for Security Analysis

description.narrative: (State Western Hemisphere Regional): .Through this activity, USAID builds regional institutional capacity to use evidence-based policy, and disseminates best practices on citizen security in the Northern Triangle. This fills a critical knowledge gap in the region on how to measure the impact of citizen security policies in the region and prepare professionals to work on public safety issues. To achieve this, USAID will train government and NGO representatives in quantitative methods and substantive topics in citizen security, deploy pilot policy projects that use impact evaluation methods, and expose the policy community to best practices in citizen security. With FY 2018 funds, USAID will host a third group of justice sector and NGO representatives in a two month training program with the Police Academy in El Salvador. Participants will implement pilot projects utilizing impact evaluation methods learned in the Academy and be mentored by the Academy professors. To promote sustainability, USAID will also finish developing a Master's Degree in Criminology. The program will use virtual and in-person curricula and will offer a joint degree from John Jay College of Criminal Justice and its partner, the Jesuit University (UCA). John Jay College of Criminal Justice is a recognized leader in the area of crime prevention and impact evaluation. Through its partnership with UCA, it has become an important ally to develop academic programs and to promote research in this area..This regional activity provides data and best practices for informed security policy making in the Northern Triangle countries, aligned with the U.S. Strategy for Central America, specifically with the Enhancing Security pillar and the Community Security line of action in the three countries. It also supports Goal 1 of the Joint Strategic Plan as it addresses violence that threatens U.S. interests, such as crime, violence, and irregular migration.. .

sector.narrative: Rule of Law and Human Rights
Rule of Law and Human Rights
Rule of Law and Human Rights

title.narrative: Social Science Research to Inform Citizen Security Policy

description.narrative: This CARSI activity aims to increase knowledge about forced displacement caused by violence, and support the development of models to address it. It will focus on establishing a regional mechanism for tracking and monitoring forced displacement in the Northern Triangle; building capacity in the three Northern Triangle countries for the creation of national protection systems specific to internal displacement; and piloting regional solutions that will improve community-based protection for displaced people.

title.narrative: Coffee Resilience Project in Central America

description.narrative: The purpose of this activity is to employ climate-smart agricultural technologies at various scales, and provide training in business skills to key segments of the coffee value chain in order to improve the livelihoods, economic opportunities, and resilience of Central American coffee farmers to climate change.

(USAID Central America Regional): The Regional Clean Energy Initiative (RCEI) improves the enabling environment for investment in clean energy in Central America, and reduces overall energy consumption at the regional level through energy efficiency practices. It supports Central American countries in their efforts toward long-term emissions reductions and commitments under the Central American Integration System's Sustainable Energy Strategy 2020. .FY 2016 funded activities will support harmonization of energy regulations, including minimum energy efficiency standards, which will facilitate the trade of energy efficient electrical equipment in Central America and further reduce greenhouse gas emissions..Through these activities, RCEI's technical assistance will ensure consumers that the equipment available in the Central American market, specifically residential refrigerators, motors and lighting equipment, are of high quality and energy efficient..

description.narrative: The activity will help USAID to continue strengthening national observatories in the Northern Triangle countries and improve regional and national institutional capacity to collect, monitor, and process security information and apply it to policy formulation. USAID will support the development of victimization surveys, regional forums and exchanges, and will continue providing technical assistance to improve citizen security information management in each country. Additionally, USAID will fund sub-grants for capacity building of governmental institutions on citizen security information management, research, and standardization of indicators.

description.narrative: Ensure full respect for the human rights of migrants in accordance with law, as well as the provision of foods, personnel support, and services to meet basic needs of vulnerable migrants.

IOM has launched a USAID-funded project: Northern Triangle Migration Management Information Initiative (NTMI), designed to strengthen the capacities of governments of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras to collect, analyse and share information on human mobility, in order to support humanitarian action and protect vulnerable populations in the three countries. The NTMI comprises four main lines of work: strengthening government capacity to record, process, analyse and communicate returnee information; generating consistent information on human mobility and how it relates to decision-making and public policy development; creating and sharing reports and information products with government and other agencies involved in assisting returnees and other vulnerable populations, with an emphasis on children and adolescents; and promoting cooperation between government agencies.

(USAID Central America Regional): A three-year grant to a Public International Organization will support actions in the Goascoran watershed shared by El Salvador and Honduras, which drains to the Gulf of Fonseca. The Improving Coastal Watersheds and Livelihoods activity will improve management of upland watersheds to expand adaptation-based mitigation practices in order to decrease emissions from forest deforestation and degradation, reduce climate vulnerability, and better conserve coastal-marine resources that form the basis of many of the region's livelihoods. It will also support continuing successful work with regional institutions, governments, and communities in the Central American region to better manage important coastal-marine areas. .

title.narrative: Partnership for Climate-Smart Agriculture" implemented by the IDB

description.narrative: Climate-Smart Agriculture Fund for Latin America and the Caribbean (the Fund") implemented by the IDB. With an initial $5 million contribution from the Global Environment Facility (GEF), loans from the fund will support private sector investments that will aim to increase agricultural productivity and yields while reducing climate vulnerability, greenhouse gas emissions, and/or enhancing biodiversity and ecosystem services.

Support the development of effective, legitimate, and democratically accountable security systems (within the statutory restrictions on providing support to law enforcement forces). Illustrative activities include the following: public sector reform and public management; strategic planning, policy, and budget formulation; building ministry capacity; civilian and civic capacity building; formal oversight (legislative, fiscal, human rights); and informal oversight (civil society watchdog groups).

Improve policies, laws, regulations, and administrative practices affecting the private sector. Includes reducing barriers to competition and unwarranted distortions to market prices; reducing policy and regulatory barriers to establishing, operating, and closing businesses; strengthening the legal framework surrounding property rights that is fair to both men and women, contract enforcement, and dispute resolution, along with the administration of those laws; reducing incentives for corruption and promoting transparent business practices; strengthening the legal framework surrounding intellectual property rights; and improving laws and regulations affecting the creation, dissemination, and use of technology. It also includes improving policies and regulations affecting technology choices and production behaviors with environmental impacts; and improving policies, laws, and regulations affecting hiring and firing of workers, wages, working conditions, and collective bargaining. Includes support for specific improvements as well as efforts to strengthen the institutions that contribute to designing and implementing further improvements.

Improve sustainability of a productive and clean environment by reducing risks to the health of the workforce and the population in general, communities, and ecosystems from environmental pollution and other environmental risks associated with industrial and agricultural production, urbanization, energy use, transport, and other human activity.

title.narrative: Title II - WFP's Protracted Relief and Recovery Operations (PRRO) - Central America Regional

description.narrative: Construction of Northern Governorates Water Supply

The USAID| Program for Strengthening the Central American Response to HIV/AIDS (PASCA) (20082013) strives to foster a strong, unified regional approach to the epidemic. PASCA is guided by three core principlesforging linkages, fostering leadership, and advancing evidence-based decisionmaking. The project uses a combined country and regional approach to achieve its objective. The project implements country-specific activities in Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Panama, as well as region-wide initiatives that include Honduras and Nicaragua. PASCA bolsters the regional response to HIV through three main strategic objectives:Enhancing implementation of regional and national HIV/AIDS strategic plans, Supporting effective implementation of national advocacy agendas, Mitigating HIV/TB co-infection by strengthening collaboration between HIV and TB programs and by placing co-infection on the regional agenda.

description.narrative: Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

participating-org.narrative: U.S. Government - U.S. Agency for International Development
